description:
It's a great omakase. You start off with some very creative prepared dishes, move on to some excellent nigiri (you can order extra, and you should after you finish the 7 pieces included in the course) a nice chaser bowl of soup and finally a light dessert.

I don't know if it's because of freshness, but I feel like fish I'd eaten before tasted different there. Very worth a stop, though a bit hard to find. It's on the top floor of the east mall (most shops are in the west mall) and the door isn't hidden but there's no big sign so you can totally miss it.
author: Misha T.

description:
I cannot stress or overplay the quality of the chef's omakase. I would say it is in my top 5 meals, and the first dish (monkfish with amaebi and truffle) was in the top 3 bites I've ever had. The waitress/hostess (who I believe is the head chef's wife) was incredibly friendly and seemed excited by our clear enjoyment of the meal. The frontage of the restaurant is nondescript, tucked away within the mall. But the decor inside is elegant and minimalistic, seating just 14 customers at a time. Despite this smaller setting, I felt like we had plenty of space and didn't feel cramped at all. Each dish was so tasty and nuanced that I could literally write a Yelp review of each. The nigiri, sashimi, miso cod, chawanmushi, strawberry mochi--everything was perfection. 

Recommendations: Full Chef Omakase, extra order of uni 

Pros: Every dish, service, decor, relatively easy to get a reservation 

Okays: n/a

Cons: n/a
author: Perry H.

description:
Best sushi in my life of 40+ years. 
And I am Japanese.
Born in Japan even.
Seriously.

Price tag seemed a bit high at the time of reservation, but we found that the portion is quite generous and the quality is exxxxcellent. Compared to New York standard pricing here is a bargain. 

I will come back in a heartbeat.
author: Neenah C.

description:
Came here for the omakase. My friend had been here before but did not sit at the bar area previously. Experience at the bar was much better, according to my friend. So choose to sit at the bar! The restaurant is small. We had a reservation. Parking was easy. There is also a parking lot if street parking isn't available. 

The fish is all imported. Fresh.  Fresh wasabi is the standard here. The meal was well paced, and the fish size was generous. Toro melted in my mouth. The scallop was very good. Everything was excellent. The only thing that was only okay was the salad. It was on the bland side for my taste. But my friends love it.  I will be back! (But after I try all the other places on my list)
author: Dawn N.

description:
This is definitely one of the better sushi bars in SF. So fresh ... hard to decide what I enjoyed most 

Also the fact that the mall is a busy sea of people and this place is a tranquil oasis makes it even more enjoyable
author: David B.

description:
庵 An in Japanese means a hermitage a secluded residence, private retreat, hideaway which implies an intimate smallness. Room is full of warm unpainted, natural wood & neutral colors.  An seats about 10 at the bar along w/ about 3 tables. One head chef & assistant, it reminds me of Urasawa in Beverly Hills in its intimate size. Definitely make a reservation. Walkins were declined on Saturday night. 

Rather formal Washoku where there is minimum of chit chat w/ the Sushi chef. The main emphasis is on the contemplation of each small dish. 

1) Lemon fish is a neutral white fish that has a fibrous resistance. Green onion chiffonade & black seeds tasting of onion.  Myer lemon mayonnaise scented potato salad. All was to be eaten simultaneously to give the lemon fish added flavour. 

1a)  Canada Spot Prawn, think of soft, wet velvet "Ama Ebi", Foie Gras of the sea Ankimo, touch of Dashi Sho-yu/bonito broth infused soy sauce gelée perfumed w/ forest earthy white truffle oil. 

2) Medley of Sashimi: O-Toro, fatty, lush, melting at mouth temperature. Chu- Toro fatty but more Tuna meaty. Kanpachi/amberjack near the belly for more firm fattiness. Madai/sea bream soft plumpiness. All had a premium sea Umami. Green Seabean garnish was briny & touch crunchy. 

3)  Chawan Mushi is loose pudding-like steamed egg custard soup. Topped w/ Ikura/salmon roe, Shi-takè mushroom, Ankake, a shiny, thickened fish broth sauce Velouté. Enoki mushroom, scallops in rustic fig shaped ceramic. 

4)  Gindara/black cod marinated in white Miso paste, baked w/ skin on & slightly caramelized. Garnished w/ pickled, brined watermelon radish & purple carrot.

5)  Blanched baby kale w/ crushed sweet white sesame seed dressing.

Sushi:

6)  Kinmedai/golden eye snapper, Chiba. 
7)  Iwana/ arctic char like a sea trout, Iceland.
8)  Kan Buri/mature winter yellow fin tuna full of fat
9)  Sayori/Japanese half beak
10) Katsuo/bonito more meaty like a tuna dressed w/ garlic ponzu fruitiness possibly from a touch of Aceto Balsamico di Modena.
11)  Hotatè/scallop soft, velvety, sweet. Iwate. 
12)  Toro from Croatia. Aged for more gamy, blood scented Umami 
13) Suimino/clear soup: 
Musky woodsy Matsu Takè mushroom from Oregon. Decorated w/ Mitsuba leaf/milder cilantro, Kamaboko/steamed fish terrine. 

1-13) Ozè Sakè (sah keh) by Ryu-jin is very dry, touch of Japanese pear, bit acidic & bitter to clear the palate for the next bite. as well as augmenting the flavours of the previous dish. 
 
Dessert:

14) Absolutely ripe, earthy, sweet, fragrant, deep dark red strawberry Daifuku/thinly coated with sweet Mochi rice purée sprinkled w/ white confectioner's sugar.
author: Gary I.

description: Friendly and cozy place.  Great service! Super good fish.  Same awesome fish distributor as some of the fanciest sushi places in town, but for half the Omakase price!  Sitting at the bar with the two chefs is highly recommended.  Sitting at the tables and not the bar in an intimate place like this would be like going to Oracle to watch the Warriors...but from the concession stand TVs.
author: Sequoia S.

description:
This place offers a really solid Omakase in the heart of SF Japantown and makes a perfect pre-movie destination.  The chef's omakase offers what I consider staples and includes:

(1). Appetizer including a spoon of ankimo and amaebi, sashimi and lemon mash potato
(2).  Sashimi course including really delicious blue fin tuna
(3).  Chawanmushi - this was a standout and was just absolutely delicious (includes scallop, shrimp, mushrooms and ikura)
(4).  Kale salad
(5).  Miso-marinated black cod - another measure of a good Japanese restaurant and this certainly passed with flying colors
(6).  The 7 piece nigiri includes golden eye snapper, hamachi, Arctic char, Saba, amber jack, scallop and toro. All of the pieces were great with the scallop being really outstanding
(7).  Delicious soup
(8).  Strawberry red bean mochi was the perfect dessert to end a good meal. 

I am being really picky by not giving this place five stars for the good food, great service and nice ambiance.  While being super solid, there was nothing that really wowed me or elevated the experience (e.g., A-5 wagyu even for a higher price).  They offer really good value and it's worth a stop if you are going to be in the area.
author: Andrew S.

description:
The place is very small maybe seats about 14 people? I'm assuming reservation only for this place. We almost didn't find the place because the store front was so inconspicuous and almost blended in with the wall. 

We were welcomed very sweetly by the hostess/waitress who already knew our group and was already expecting us. 

But anyways, My first omakase experience! My boyfriend treated me to some fancy Japanese food for my birthday. I could not have felt more spoiled.

We ordered the Chef's omakase and absolutely everything was amazing. I have no other omakase experiences to compare to else but everything was seriously AMAZING. This is probably what Japan tastes like, as a matter of fact , I think the hostess did mention some of fish being imported from Japan and Spain and elsewhere. 

Nigiri, all was fresh and unlike any I have ever had. Top quality sashimi , perfection. Now just plain ok sushi won't cut it anymore. I'm hooked. After having An , all other sushi has not been the same. 

There were quite a few dishes but my favorite was... can I say everything?! The sea bass stood out and the hot miniature pot of soup was really unique.

Underrated.
author: A Z Flor H.

description: We came here on a Tuesday night and it wasn't busy at all. My friend & I had the 8 course Omakase for $85 which is very affordable for it's high quality Omakase. It was very delicious! I've been to Sushizanmai Bekkan at Tsukiji and I say An's quality is pretty good. Our chef is from Yokohama and he's really nice. It was just a great experience overall! I would love to go back to try the rest of the menu.
author: Susan H.

description:
It's a cute little restaurant that has 4 small tables and sushi bar seating. The service was great and I enjoyed the ambiance of the restaurant.

Ordered the $85, 8 course chef's omakase. The food was delicious but seemed like the simple omakase I can get at cheaper restaurants. The black cod, amberjack sashimi, and toro nigiri had great texture. I've been to similar restaurants for their omakase for around the same price and in my opinion, they have been a lot better.
author: Jenn H.

description:
There were so many things I liked about this place but also a few things that let me down.  BTW, we ordered the chef's omakase for $85/pp...such a steal in the city nowadays.  

First things first, the sushi rice was excellent.  The fish was fresh.  We were told where each and every single one came from and they did have a large variety from tsujiki fish market in Japan.  

We were given a starter with a pre-made spoon of ankimo and amaebi served with a side of albacore with lemon mashed potatoes.  I was a little bummed to see the spoons come out of the fridge and immediately onto the plate.  I was hoping for that finesse that you receive from sushi chefs during any omakase meal.  Just little details...such as the mashed potatoes being violently scooped out of the container and onto the plate.  It just felt like Thanksgiving dinner instead of a semi high quality meal.  It also just drives me nuts when sushi chefs precut your nigiri pieces and let them sit in the fridge in front of you until you've reached that part of your meal.  

Ok, now that we've got the negatives out of the way...I had the best chawan mushi ever here at An.  It was delicious and packed with ingredients such as ikura, protein, and mushrooms.  Amazing.  The sesame kale was ok...a nice cold touch in between some of the warmer dishes.  The miso black cod was perfectly made and the flavors were spot on.  

I enjoyed our nigiri pieces. They were mostly served without all the extra stuff that peeps put on them nowadays.  Just fish and sushi rice...which I appreciated.  We were also given a bowl of fish broth and a piece of homemade strawberry, red bean mochi.  Great way to end the meal.

Service was fantastic.  Our tea cups were refilled numerous times and our server was friendly.  The sushi chef was pretty quiet in the beginning but he ended up being a little more talkative towards the middle of our meal.  Getting a reservation was easy.  We called 30 minutes prior to opening and had no prob getting a seat at the sushi bar.  

4 stars and super affordable for omakase.
author: Jen W.

description: Best omakase i had in SF. Brought my mother who enjoys sushi and sashimi, and my roommate who was not as familiar with Japanese cuisine in general here. All three of us really enjoyed their omakase. Try to ask chefs what's fresh cuz they have different nigiri daily.
author: Soojin J.

description:
I'm puzzled.  I thought I knew all of the sushi places, especially omakase style.  My friend's office is literally across the street from here, and we frequent Japan Town quite a bit, but An Japanese somehow escaped us.

It's a breath of fresh air when you can find good places for under $100, and An is just making the cut...but barely.  It is a good value, but there were some misses.

Service was great.  The chawan mushi was great.  It was the mackerel that was a downer for me.  I know it's supposed to have that oily fishy taste, but this one was just a little too overpowering for me.  

I'll be back solely on the price and the location.
author: Ron L.

description: Walking into An is like walking into a sushi restaurant in Tokyo.  The ambiance and food transports you into another world.  We had the special Omakase menu and it was amazing.
author: Maria R.

description:
[ Food ] The omakase was your basic nigiri + other side courses. I enjoyed the majority of it, but some of the fish (mackerel, o-toro, and snapper ) had a terrible, pungent odor. Furthermore, there wasn't any nigiri that I felt was super unique or exemplary. I felt like I could get the same at any other omakase restaurant in the city.

[ Service ] Service was excellent! Our waitress came around to refill our hot tea cups every half hour and was super prompt at removing any unused dishes/trash. She was super nice and friendly. 

[ Value ] Even though the omakase is cheaper than most of the other places in SF, $80 can get you a way better deal at Sushi Hon, Hinata, Tsubasa, or Robin. I would definitely recommend checking out other spots for the same price point and comparing; $80 is still very expensive for a meal--remember that! 

Tip: This place can be kind of difficult to find, but it's right next to the upstair's restrooms. There is no sign, just a door. Also, reservations are always recommended for any omakase restaurant, but this place was nearly empty on a Saturday (only us and one other party were dining) so it's a good spot if you're craving omakase without a reservation and don't want to wait.
author: Chanel C.

description:
To me this seemed very traditional. A small spot where we sat at the bar and ordered the very reasonably priced omakase menu with cooked items. Everything appeared to be very authentic. If I were to only mention one critique it would be that they pre made some of items on the menu which took away from the experience a little. It's hard to face the bar and not notice the spoons coming right out of the fridge, and I understand the anticipation and save of time but It just seemed a little disappointing.

Presentation was definitely on point and flavors were great. Service was good also. I would recommend coming here at least once. We'll definitely be back at some point.
author: Guisela L.

description: Very good little sushi place in Japantown.  Surprisingly it's not that crowded.  I would recommend the omakase.
author: Eric C.

description:
High quality no-frills sushi is an expensive habit. I don't know about you, but I sure as hell can't afford $200+ per person for fish and rice on a regular basis. Basically, I'm poor and need a sponsor. Seeking Arrangement, anyone?

An is probably the best sushi you can get in the city for the price point. Omakase is $80 per person and I left the meal feeling full without needing to order extra pieces. Thank goodness for this semi-affordable spot because I'm a little too old to be a desirable sugar baby.
author: Suany W.

description:
The first time we came here was by accident, but the food and service was excellent.

For the second time, we made a reservation at the sushi counter.  For most of the evening, it was just my wife and I and the owner chatting while he prepared one perfect bite of sushi after another.  

If you are interested in a omakase sushi experience without breaking the bank, An is a great place.  The owner/chef is completely passionate about sushi and is very friendly.  His wife rounds out the experience with impeccable service.  We really love this place.
author: Troy S.

description:
My quest to find the best omakase continues, in which I find An to be a strong contender. 

My all time favorite omakase is clear and can be found on my profile, but I think An has a distinct and valuable place on the totem clear. Come here for a no frills, classically authentic omakase at an excellent value. You won't get any fancy sauces or cheery conversation from the chef, or real wasabi root for the matter - which I do think they should rectify. But you will get 12 pieces of fresh, expertly selected nigiri for $70 that will satisfy any craving you might have. You can even order a la carte and have a very filling dinner of quality sushi for $50 pp. 

I'm not sure if this will change as more people find out about An, but it is currently quite easy to get a reservation, and doesn't require planning months in advance like several other spots in the city. So in that sense, An is a true neighborhood gem in the heart of Japantown for people who want nothing but sushi. An is not in the same class as many of its would-be competitors, but I don't believe it tries or even wants to be. Just sit down and dig in.
author: Lana T.

description:
Came for the $80 12 piece omakase dinner. I took one step in and the place smelled like frying oil, so that was not a good start. I didn't see any tempura served so it was puzzling.

Nigiri rice tasted like it was made a few hours ago for lunch service, all clumped together and a little dry.  A few fish pieces tasted like they just came out of the refrigerator. The selection was pretty good but the quality is more fitting of a $40 course.
author: Thomas C.

description: Recommend the omakase. The chef's passion for quality and simplicity is easily visible in his menu choices.  Look forward to returning soon.
author: Scot S.

description:
To celebrate my birthday and the fact that I'm an Asian foodie who has lived 29 long years without ever having tried omakase, we came to An in Japantown for a long dinner.  We considered two options: the $75 nigiri omakase (12pc nigiri) or the $80 chef's omakase with 7pc nigiri + sashimi, 2 hot items (atsumono) and dessert.

The ambience is really relaxed, clean and modern, seating for under 20 people and it was not crowded on Friday night, they play tasteful jazz music softly in the background.  You feel like you're at an unknown little sushi bar in Tokyo (all the staff are Japanese).


---- CHEF'S OMAKASE ----

Zensai:  3.5 stars
The ankimo-white truffle oil spoonful was interesting but a bit too dry.  Would have been perfect with some sauce.  The sesame kale was yummy but standard.

Sashimi:  3.5 stars
Maguro (not my favourite) and Tai (sea bream) was decent, but a bit dry so I didn't think it was very fresh.

Squid Tomato Salad:  3 stars
The baby squid tasted a little stale, but went well with the fresh cherry tomatoes.

Chawan Mushi (Atsumono 1):  2.5 stars
Served in a gorgeous artisan clay vessel, but the chawanmushi itself and its ingredients (scallop, mushrooms) were overcooked.  I've made pretty decent chawan mushi at home, so this is not acceptable.

Black Cod (Atsumono 2):  4.5 stars
Just, yes.  When in doubt, I always order the black cod.  This one was grilled to perfection, just didn't come with the sweet sticky sauce.

Nigiri:  4.5 stars
1.  Goldeneye Red Snapper (Kinmedai)  Loved this one.  Beautiful colour, with crispy red skin.
2.  Arctic Char (Iwana).  Salmon-coloured tender deliciousness.  My partner's favourite
3.  Filefish:  Whitefish topped with its own fried fatty liver.  Yum
4.  Sardine:  Best sardine I've had in my life
5.  Bluefin Tuna:  Really yummy, for tuna.  Fatty, tender, melt-in-mouth
6.  Otoro:  Mmmm toro.
7.  Hotategai:  Fantastic fresh and soft raw scallop, not tough or chewy

Soup:  4 stars
I love love love clear soups (aka broth).  So hard to get MSG-free ones in the US.  Fish broth with scrumptious fresh fat-stemmed mushrooms, an airy slice of tofu, sweet fishcake.

Dessert:  3.5 stars
Strawberry sorbet.  Tasted freshly-homemade but I'm much more of an ice-cream person.

Verdict:  4.5 stars
Skip the cooked dishes but the nigiri is fabulous.  Now I see why the Nigiri Omakase is worth $75, maybe not the best in SF but fantastic for the $75-80 price range.  I would love to try Kusakabe, Omakase, etc. but will definitely also come back to An again for the great value.
author: Letitia L.

description:
Koo was my all-time favorite sushi spot from 2007-2011. Chef Kiyoshi was the sushi master behind the bar and his adorable wife Ayumi always attended to guests warmly and made all the desserts on the menu from scratch! Together I always thought of them to be a #PowerCouple in the Sushi restaurant business in San Francisco (I also think they're both attractive and adorable at the same time to be quite frank). In contrast, I felt that Ino and his wife were always so grumpy and negative to customers unless they were Japanese and/or been continuous regulars to their sushi bar.

Congrats on your retirement Ino and I wish you and your wife the best, but I am ecstatic now that Kiyoshi and Ayumi have taken over this space to make it their own!

In recent years, with the plethora of sushi bars popping up around the Bay Area, I've continuously felt the need to play this catch- up game and try them all and figure out which one I like best.

An feels like the original kind of sushi bar. The kind that doesn't over-do their sushi with sauces and gold flakes but stays true to its Japanese roots. A true, no frills, just simply-amazing sushi place.

In regards to the ambiance, the color scheme/decorations/plating have changed a bit but the actual storefront/layout/bar/tables are the same.

The menu is straightforward but still flexible enough where you can order the way you'd like! There are 3 different Omakases, two that are nigiri-focused: $50-7 pc, or $75- 12 pc, and $80 for the "Chef's Omakase" which includes sashimi, two warm dishes, as well as 7 pc nigiri.

I dined at the bar and decided to order a la carte instead. I went for about 9 Nigiris, the Fish Bone Soup, & Ayumi's home made green tea mochi ice cream - and spent about $66 out the door.

For me, An has it all - an inviting ambiance, a plain and simple sushi bar as well as a couple of tables should you come in a party of 3 or 4, and ultimately, the highest quality sushi from all over the world with perfect fish to rice proportions. The shari is packed perfectly and won't break, whether you use chopsticks or fingers.

I'm being picky here, but it would be amazing if they had real freshly grated wasabe. Other than that, An's my new favorite. I can finally say that I have found my Go-To sushi spot in the city again. An is it.
author: Veronica S.

description: My mom and I was on vacation in San Francisco, and we were checking out Japantown. After checking out the shops, we decided on dinner at this restaurant. We had to wait at least 15-20 minutes for a seat. It was a very small restaurant with sushi bar and a few small tables. The dinner menu, to me, was very limited and pricey. I guess the sushi chef noted that I was hesitant on the order and advised that the Omakase is the best choice. I wanted to see if I can share the Omakase with my mom (trying to save my budget), and I guess I misunderstood him because he ended up serving to both of us. I liked the attention and explanation he gave for each serving, and overall it was a decent meal, but I kind of still felt I was hungry after. Not sure if I would give it another try the next time, but for people who like the chef's attention and or the details on the food served, this is not a bad choice.
author: Wendy T.

description:
Me and the bf came to An for our valentine's dinner (because he knows the real way to my heart is through SUSHI!). 

We both decided to ordered the nigiri omakase, which comes with an appetizer, 12 pieces of fish, and soup. 

The first plate we got had a spoon with ankimo, amaebi, ponzu gelee, and black truffle and next to it was baby kale with a delicious dressing. OH MY GOD. They just went all out with this plate. It definitely set the bar for the rest of the meal. I could probably eat 10 of the spoons and I would die happy. 

The following are what was included in the omakase: 
Akamatsu (small grouper)
Kinme-dai (deep sea red snapper)
Iwana (arctic char) 
Mirugai (giant clam) 
Hotategai (scallop)
Sayori (halfbeaks) 
Shima Aji (stripe jack)
Katsuo (Bonito tuna) 
Uni 
Kawahagi (filefish)
Buri (wild winter yellowtail) 
Toro

We also ordered:
Amaebi 
Kamasu (barracuda)
Anago (sea eel)
Tamago


Each piece was incredible. Most of the fish were served by itself versus having it already dressed, so it's more traditional. Everything was fresh, and the favorites for me were the arctic char, scallop, wild winter yellowtail and toro. We ordered one chawanmushi to split since it looked delicious. HIGHLY recommend. 

Make reservations and request to sit at the sushi bar! There's only about 16 seats in the entire restaurant, so once word gets out, I'm sure reservations will begin to get harder and harder.
author: Noelle H.

description:
My Yelp pen pal experiences have been quite haphazard since the very beginning. From your typical "I'm in town let's meet and have dinner" to "Will you marry me I have a yacht, let's sail all over the world," and anything in between. Some did result in delightful encounters: one prior example was a man who interviewed me and wrote about my experience with Princess cake for a Swedish American magazine, and another, was a retire elite college professor, who goes to Japan on a regular interval but otherwise spends his time in San Francisco. He told me about An, after returning from Tokyo in November. Our correspondences since then have ranged from world travel to world cuisine, and of course in the back of my head I kept on trying to make my way to An. He said that it's as good as Shiro's, and any number of good restaurants in Japan.

He would be right. Three months since it opened, I finally snagged a reservation.

I understand in 2016, a restaurant named Omakase was awarded a Michelin star in San Francisco. That seemed odd. It's like naming your daughter Meili, which in Chinese means Beautiful, wouldn't it be a bit too declasse and gauche? That said, in a good Japanese restaurant, you should go with the omakase menu, out of respect for the chef, and out of respect for your wallet. The talented chefs often assemble the best they know how, and you'd enjoy it in the sequence that you should be enjoying them at. And you get a good value for the money you are about to spend. Just like they do in Japan.

Such was the case at An. Get the nigiri omakase if you are into sushi, or for $5 more, get the omakase which gives you more than enough sample of a fine Japanese cuisine, from start to finish, it's the best $80 you'd ever spend.

On the nigiri omakase menu, you get to have the fried fish bones to go with the aji, so if you don't go for it, try to order it on the side, the fish bone, as my retired globe trotting professor told me, is not to be missed. On both omakase menus, you do get the starter that should immediately signal you that this is about a journey, a food journey that will leave you wanting for more: kale salad with sesame dressing, monk fish liver with sweet shrimp and jelly. Do take advantage of that palette cleanser before you are presented with a bowl of sashimi. Their varies selection of tuna, including toro, are of similar quality as Tsukiji Fish Market's sushi restaurant. No one who has eaten at that market would be disappointed by the quality that is served at An.

The show continues with steamed egg custard and then the parade of carefully assembled seven piece nigiri. If your neighbor is having the nigiri omakase, he/she will be on the 2nd round of their nigiri plate. 

Good rice to fish portion. Excellent quality of rice, not too soft not too firm and just perfect temperature. However, it's their fresh and REAL wasabi that kicked the food up a notch.

Finished the meal with a clear broth fish soup and then sorbet. 

I wrote to the professor after, and told him that I thoroughly enjoyed his recommendation. We were speculating the comings and goings of the next possible Michelin star award in 2017. Wako, as it turned out, received a one star in 2016, before he had tried, but after I had dined there, when it just opened. He's afraid, that An would turn into another Wako. I'm not exactly that worried, I think time would tell. Plus, we are convinced its odd location may not attract the non devotees. it's not the Mission or Russian Hill, this is the ghetto burb, straddling between Laurel Heights and Western Addition, and just so ever so closely tied to Inner Richmond aka the Avenues. For food enthusiasts, we know a diamond in the rough when we see one, and for selfish reasons, we'd like it to stay that way. 

He ends his communique by saying that he wishes that it never changes and no (Michelin) star would ever been assigned. I suspect the word is already out, and it may be a tad too late for that. But, if and when that day does come, we could at least say, "we've been there from the beginning."
author: Victoria E.

description:
Going to An was something that I had wanted to do after reading about for awhile, but since reservations are hard to come by and requiring making a phone call, I had been delaying it.  That's when one of my friends took the initiative and made reservations for the two of us and we went to dinner to enjoy the highly discussed omakase options that start at $50.  I'm inherently skeptical of reasonably priced sushi, especially in San Francisco, but was willing to go out on a leap of faith that An was as good as everyone said it was.  

My friend decided to go with the 12 piece nigiri Omakase option that was $75 and I went the more economical path of selecting the 7 piece nigiri Omakase option that came with kanpyo maki.  Both omakase options came with soup and an amuse bouche to start.  

To start off, this place is tiny.  So if you're a loud talker, someone who enjoys a lot of personal space, or coming with a large (5+) group, this place probably isn't for you.  An is definitely an intimate place, so be prepared to get cozy with your neighbors.

Everything we had that night was incredible and the freshness of the fish was definitely the most noteworthy item.  My favorite was the katsuo nigiri I had that came topped with green onion and garlic.  At the end, we decided to blow it up big time by checking out the ala carte menu and got an order of ankimo and the Wagyu nigiri.  I prefer Kusakabe's Wagyu nigiri, but this was absolutely worth the $8 add-on.  I'm not a huge fan of ankimo, but the few bites I had were absolutely delicious.  The entire evening was great where we sat at the sushi bar, got to watch everything get assembled in front of us, and enjoyed hanging out with our chefs.  I will definitely be back here with my husband, the effort of trying to get a seat at An is absolutely worth it!
author: Lisa I.

description:
"And another one," as DJ Khaled would say. In this case, another amazing omakase for the books.

Shawn C. took me here for our Valentine's Day dinner. :') The struggle was deciding whether we were gonna do the Chef's Omakase at $80 per person, or the 12 Piece Nigiri Omakase at $75 per person. We ended up choosing the Chef's Omakase, since we wanted to try a variety of dishes and upon evaluating the nigiri per piece prices, they were pretty reasonably priced so we could always order more if our hearts desired. 

Good choice, because I really enjoyed everything we had! Highlights include:

- Zensai was a baby kale salad and a spoonful of ankimo with amaebi topped with black truffle and ponzu jelly. This was DELICIOUSSSS. 

- Chawanmushi was our second warm dish, egg custard with shrimp, scallops and ikura. It was light, yet flavorful. Good news: you can order this by itself off the menu. 

- I may have found my new favorite fish, Iwana aka Artic Char. Buttery, melt in your mouth, amazing. 

- TORO. No need to say anything else. 

- We each ordered 3 additional nigiris after the 7 that were included in the Chef's Omakase: tamago, salmon and akamutsu (small grouper). HIGHLY RECOMMEND getting the akamutsu a-la-carte if it isn't apart of your nigiri omakase. Texture was fatty, buttery, perfect. 

We dined at KUSAKABE recently, and agreed that An seems more traditional, simple, a back to basics type of place. The focus is really on the fish, since most were not pre-seasoned. It's slightly less pricier than KUSAKABE, and you have the option of not ordering any of the omakases and just ordering off their menu, if you wish. 

We really enjoyed our dining experience with Minoru-san and hope to be back soon when it won't make our wallets cry. :)
author: Laverne N.

description:
What a gem! Officially one of our favorite Omakase spots in NYC and SF. Omakase at $80 pp is an absolute steal. Personally prefer it over $125-150 pp Omakase at Nobu and Morimoto.

Intimate ambiance and all dishes are traditionally prepared. Excellent overall. I was amazed I was able to get a same day reservation at the sushi bar on a Sat night!
author: CC B.

description:
The whole experience was worth while. It's located in the center of Japantown, SF where I had never been. Japantown itself is amazing, and a must see for all visitors.

I was looking for a good Omakase in San Francisco and I must say I was not disappointed. The chef was very clear with the descriptions of each fish. They were all imported from Japan except for one. 

Service was great, the Sake recommendation was on point and fairly priced!
author: Henrique M.

description:
4.5 STARS

So long, Ino. See you never...

There's no question that Ino aka the Sushi Nazi made the BEST ankimo (foie gras of the sea)...ever. But dayaaaam, he was hella grumpy...like haven't been laid in 50 years "grumpy".  

Before it was publicly announced that Ino was closing, I wanted to pay him a farewell visit. I tried making reservations three times (he doesn't accept walk-ins) only to get yelled at: "NOOOOOO, reservations!!!" and the phone to get slammed at my face...by Ino himself (twice) and then by his wife.

I hope they're now enjoying their retirement and having infinite amounts of happy endings. Lawd knows they need them endorphins!

I was excited to learn that the owners of Koo would be talking over. Koo was one of my fav sushi restaurants in SF that I visited weekly for 3-4 years with an old ex. Man, I miss those Spoonfuls of Happiness! 

While Koo's new sister restaurant, An has their infamous Spoonfuls of Happiness on the menu, you won't find Godzilla or Dragon rolls here.  It's strictly edomae-style sushi with 3 omakase choices ($50, $75, $80) along and a la carte menu of nigiri, sashimi, and hot & cold dishes. Beer, wine, and sake only. $30 minimum at the sushi bar (this is very easy to do). Reservations highly recommend as (seating for 16).

My friend and I both ordered the Nigiri Omakase which comes with a zensai (appetizer), 12 pieces of nigiri and soup for $75: http://bit.ly/1PxRi6e.

Before your meal is served, you will receive an oshibori (hot wet towel) to clean your hands. This way you can eat the nigiri with your hands; my preferred method. I don't want to be THAT girl who drops her nigiri in the soy sauce, only for it to splatter all over herself and her dining companion's white dress shirt.

*Zensai - Ankimo w/ black truffle & ponzu jelly & Go-mae: http://bit.ly/1MSbTTW
*Kampachi Toro: http://bit.ly/1lg6XvS
*Iwana: http://bit.ly/1MkkSHP
*Kinmedai: http://bit.ly/1L6BctO
*Kamasu: http://bit.ly/1M2cIGj
*Shima Aji: http://bit.ly/20HeFzA
*Saba: http://bit.ly/1MSc7KI
*Akamatsu: http://bit.ly/1lg7yxu
*Saba, kelp wrapped: http://bit.ly/1L6BpgO
*Katsuo: http://bit.ly/1kkSRJt
*Hotategai: http://bit.ly/1PxR8vx
*Otoro: http://bit.ly/1HCMZ2R
*Uni w/ ika: http://bit.ly/1Nn0d5K
*Matsutake Mushroom & Tofu Soup: http://bit.ly/1SDBWgh

From start to finish, while every course was solid, I definitely favored the nigiri over the cold and hot dish courses. I loved that the red vinegar flavored shari was bite-sized so you can easily enjoy the nigiri with one mouthful. The shari was very lightly seasoned and held together well. All the fish and seafood selections were undoubtedly fresh with the favs being the kampachi toro, shima aji, saba, hotate, and otoro because of the silky fattiness. This is more of a preference but I would have preferred that Kiyoshi dress each nigiri with soy and his choice accoutrements as one can overdo it when dressing it with soy sauce themselves.  

Even though I was stuffed, I couldn't resist ordered one piece of the Japanese A5 Wagyu Nigiri ($8/piece): http://bit.ly/1PxRhzg. It's lightly torched so some of the oils are released making it one bite filled with beefy butteryness. 

If you've experienced Ino's manstrual banshee moods (he gave zero phucks and would publicly shame customers), rest assured you won't experience it here. The owner, Kiyoshi and his wife, Ayumi are incredibly welcoming, sweet, and attentive. Since they softly opened, we were the only customers at the sushi bar that night so everything was leisurely paced, but not slow. The omakase took about 70 minutes. 

The ambiance and décor hasn't changed much from when it was Ino. It's a place to have an enjoyable and peaceful meal for 2-4 people max. Please save the ratchetness and sake bombs for elsewhere. 

Beware if you're parking on the street and don't leave anything visible in your car. My friend parked on Geary and the car in front had their windows smashed...at 6 pmish.

Thank you, Kiyoshi and Ayumi for a wonderful omakase experience. Maybe you can convince Ino to give you his ankimo recipe? =D
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
We ended up here after not being able to get in at State Bird in time to make our show. After finding An on Yelp, we were lucky enough to be able to get in at this ~15 seat restaurant hidden on the second floor of the mini-mall in Japantown. 

Because we were out for our anniversary, we decided to get the Omikase menu ($80/person) to get a taste of everything. It also happened to be the best deal on the menu (in my opinion). 

Everything we had ended up being great, even the things that we would never have ordered. The fist was all exceptionally fresh and clearly high quality. While the nigiri was definitely my favorite course (toro, golden snapper, scallops, to name a few highlights), the miso black cod was also a favorite. 

The surprising dish was definitely the egg custard with lobster, salmon roe, mushrooms and fish broth. The textures were an interesting combination and it definitely tasted like the ocean. 

I could have done without the soup which was basically broth with a few mushrooms in it, but overall this was a great experience.
author: Jaime R.

description: One of the best Japanese restaurant we have ever had. We have been to Morimoto in Napa and this place is up to par in regards to the food. The Omakase I think was better at An than Morimoto. The place is small but if you are craving for authentic Japanese food this is the place to go.
author: Andy T.

description:
5 star sashimi.  We went with the Omakase, and each piece was simply delicious and fresh.  Service is attentive and nice, nothing like the previous owner (Ino sushi).

Reservations are hard, but if you go right when they open, you might get lucky.
author: Karen L.

description: I made a reservation yesterday for a seat at the bar. I ordered the chef omakase which included seven pieces of nigirizushi, appetizers, soup, and desert. The sushi was very soft and delicate and melts right in your mouth. The chef was also very helpful with informing the contents of the dishes.
author: Kevin H.

description:
Absolutely a great tasting experience!
Almost materials from Tokyo Fish Market.
Owner is 65+ and runs this place by his passion. 
He has taken over from a  previous management that had set a remarkable case of sushi in the city, and he is keeping on.
Go there if you love samplers, not big rolls (covered by non Japanese creamy sauces...)
author: Marco S.

description:
We were a bit nervous when our reservation got pushed back because of the city-wide power outage...nothing like raw fish when the fridges may not have been working for hours.  But An still delivered in spades.

We were looking for an omakase under $100, with a traditional/intimate slant.  All the omakase in the city are either extremely expensive, at places geared toward fusion rolls, or painfully boring (let's face it, you don't want just standard maguro/hamachi/ebi/unagi if you're paying for omakase).  An delivered in spades.

We ordered the $80 PP nigiri omakase.  The fish was fresh, power outage be damned.  The price point reasonable (for sushi, people, for sushi!).  The selections impeccable...we had a phenomenal range of rare and excellent cuts.  Flying fish, barracuda, o-toro (YES!), clam, scallop, aji, hirame...all fantastic.  One nice touch is that they asked us if there was anything we didn't like, and my wife said that she did not like uni, even though her husband (me) loved it.  Instead of serving us both the same course, they served me the best uni I've had in years, and gave my wife a beautiful portion of fresh crab...they really listened and customized the experience for both of us.

I also felt our chef was watching what we LOVED vs liked (because there wasn't a bad dish here) and catered our next round of fish to what resonated with us the best.

It was so worth the money.  So many interesting choices, so many choices that were on the higher range of the a-la-carte menu, never once did we get the feeling that we were getting anything other than the best fish of the day, specialized for us personally.

We had a carafe of sauvignon blanc, and on top of the fish, the omakase included a tasty ankimo spoon, pieces of fish (I forget which!) served with a dollop of mashed potato (which sounds awful but was a perfect flavor balance), sesame kale, and a fish broth soup to end.  All was excellent, except for the kale and I just don't enjoy kale to begin with so that was probably me, not them.

Our new spot.  It should be yours, too!
author: James S.

description:
The quest for the best sushi in SF can lead many astray.  

You may fall for head fakes that have great ambience but are somehow expecting that this should make up for any compromise in sushi craft and quality (Wako and Pabu both respectable but come to mind in this category).

But I digress:  An is an absolute labor of love.  Tucked between low quality tourist traps in Japantown, the location may chase away sushi lovers, but don't be fooled, this is an experience to be had over and over!  The Chef's Omakase is always out of this world good!  

They have an assortment of extremely fresh fish both locally and internationally (including Japan and Spain).

The staff members are extremely friendly and they provide excellent service and the price is a fraction of comparable quality restaurants in SF.

Go once and become a regular...
author: Bruce B.

description:
I was very excited to try An as it has been highly recommended by my good friend. I made a reservation for a friend out of town and decided to try the omakaze. 

First they have very good selection of sake and really appreciate waitress having high knowledge level and we loved what she had recommended. 

The omakaze started well with some unique, delicious courses. What I wasn't so impressed with was the sashimi and sushi. Sashimi wasn't too exciting. I enjoyed a few pieces but and in fact I stopped taking pictures of it because i think I had lost excitement. 

Rice was cold, a bit on the harder side, fish was mediocre. 

I don't think I will come back for omakaze or sushi.
author: Sarah K.

description: The best Japanese restaurant in SF by far. Chef's omasake is amazing. Service is kind and fast. It's pricy but worths every dime.
author: Ozan B.

description: I love this place! If I could afford this monthly, I would come here monthly! I am pretty sure that there was not a dish that I did not like. The service and the chef were extremely nice and endearing. I will definitely come back again to treat myself one day!
author: Alejandra R.

description: This place has the best sushi preparedness. Unbelievable sushi! Only place to go in Japantown
author: Andrew W.

description:
It's been two years that my wife and I moved in to San Francisco and it's been two years we tried to find the same Japanese taste we had when we went to Fukuoka, Hiroshima, Tokyo, etc... 

...and we just found it!

We had the Omakase Sushi, it was exactly what we were looking for! Original and classic in the mean time, super fresh and perfectly executed.
We strongly recommends this place, even if it is not so easy to find and it is in a big building, you feel like in a little house inside (An!) when you are seated.
author: A P.

description:
What a relief that An has taken over the cute little restaurant that used to be Ino Sushi (Ino was terrible). I made a same day dinner reservation on a Friday after learning that I got a big fat raise to celebrate with my boyfriend. I'm assuming An is still relatively new because securing bar seating at a good sushi restaurant is notoriously hard in this city.

Between the two of us, we ordered two 12 piece Nigiri Omakases ($75 each) and 1 Sashimi Omakase ($75), and we were STUFFED to the max. The quality and variety of fish offered here is on par with Omakase and Kusakabe at a more economical price. What's lacking here are the little details in presentation and service that Omakase and Kusakabe are flawless at. An pales in this respect but it's a much more casual and friendly atmosphere that is still excellent. 

The o-toro nigiri and negi-toro hand roll finale was an amazing end to this meal. Definitely let the chef know that this is your jam if you're sitting at the bar!
author: Catherine C.

description:
An is more like a 3.5 star rating. Taking over the infamous Ino Sushi spot, An has the same owners as Koo in the Inner Sunset, an old favorite of mine. An is located in the Peace Plaza Mall and quite small - sushi counter, 4 tables, etc. 

I thought the sushi and the fish was solid, but the nigiri omakase was $75, which seemed a tad high for a slightly rushed experience. Compare that to $85 at Wako, $95 at Kusakabe, etc, it seems to fall a bit short of expectations. 

There were a few standouts such as the barracuda, otoro, uni, and the negitoro, but overall, I found the experience average. They also offer plenty of a la carte options and "chef's daily special" menu that starts around $30-$50, which sounds quite reasonable. 

The service is as sweet as can be, and the chef, while not overly garrulous, is friendly and knowledgeable.
author: Kate M.

description: This place was pretty good: $80 for a nigiri omakase. The fish tasted fresh and flavorful. The one thing slightly different than other places is the fish was a bit warmer and slightly drier than others. I'm not sure if coming on a Thursday night was the reason or if their refrigerators (where they keep the fish) is a tad higher in temperature than other places. Their Hokkaido scallop was amazing though as well as the Japanese Uni.
author: Thomas C.

description:
After being open for 5 months, I finally made my way over to An Restaurant. It feels like this restaurant is still a little under the radar as there were seats open when we arrived for our reservations at 7:45pm on a Wednesday night.

Since we had reservations, we were give bar counter seats. We knew we wanted omakase so we asked the chef if he recommends the $80 or $75 menu options. After the meal we were glad we went with the $80 menu as the hot dishes were equally outstanding.

Overall, I am wowed by the freshness of the fish here. Chef Hayakawa also offers some unique fishes that I have never had before. I'll certainly be back for more!

Also, don't forget to admire the pretty dish for your soy sauce! Very simple yet well thought through restaurant. Thanks chef!
author: Mindy C.

description:
The restaurant is so unassuming that me and the boyfriend had a bit of trouble finding this place. It's located in the Japantown mall and it's so new that it's not on the mall map! Look for ino sushi instead. 

I highly recommend sitting at the bar with Kiyoshi (+1 for ACTUALLY Japanese chefs... yes I'm judging you Kusakabe and Omakase). Me and the boyfriend both got the nigiri omakase for $75 each. It's a great deal for the quality and variety of fish. I eat omakase fairly often and was surprised to try a couple of new pieces here -- including sanma (Japanese pike fish), a fatty and sweet fish that is only found in late autumn in Northern Japan as it swims down from Hokkaido (fun fact that I learned from Kiyoshi). 

The al a carte nigiri menu was also very reasonably priced. We had some A5 wagyu and it was so buttery. A whole plate of ankimo is only $10! The tamago is made daily in house and you can really tell how much care goes into this. It's moist, slightly sweet without being overly eggy and has no air pockets. It's not included in the omakase but that's okay because it's so cheap at $3 a piece that you're getting a better deal by having an extra piece of fish in the omakase instead. 

The only negative thing I have to say is that the rice could be a bit warmer/softer. Sushi purists will say that having the perfect rice is key but I think that's a difference that most people won't appreciate anyways. So no points docked!
author: Xinxin W.

description: Very good sushi and fresh. Service was very warm and friendly. I would highly recommend eating here, tuna rolls are so fresh and good!
author: Northcounty R.

description: We went here for Omakase; the owner used to work at Koo (which is another excellent sushi place), so we had high expectations. We were not let down. The extended omakase features soup and other interesting appetizers. There was an emphasis on citrus-y aftertastes, and hints of smoke flavor. The nigiri itself was also quite good and fresh. The only thing I did not enjoy much was the bench against the wall, it is rock hard and my back started feeling it a bit. The place is tucked inside Japantown and it's particularly cozy. Make sure to get reservations.
author: George A.

description: Excellent sushi. If what you are looking for is well-prepared fish, a nice atmosphere, and reasonable prices, this is a good choice.  The chef will be as talkative or as silent as you desire (if you are sitting at the sushi bar).  The desserts, made by the chef's wife, were excellent.  My son chose this restaurant to celebrate his birthday.  They brought him a chocolate cake on the house.  My husband and I did the larger chef's tasting menu, and we got dessert with that.  It was a mochi-wrapped strawberry.  Very interesting, delicate, flavorful--and beautifully presented.
author: s t.

description: Probably the best value omakase I've had in SF so far. High quality fish, lots of variety, and attention to detail from the sushi chef. Very small, intimate environment and feels authentic. No frills, just good sushi.
author: Aakash P.

description:
Loved their sushi, but was not as impressed by the cooked dishes.

Their toro was delicious.

The mushroom soup was not great.

The miso black cod lacked texture.

Will stick to the sushi in future.
author: David T.

description:
I can't decide if I want to give a 2 star or 3 star. My girlfriend came recently and said it was bad, but I thought to myself maybe it's an off night......It was bad! Very bad! I'm super disappointed in this meal. The price point is like Ju-Ni and Kusakabe, but the food isn't even comparable. The place wasn't packed at all and it's a super small place. 2 choices for $80. Chef's omakase w/ 7 piece nigiri, cooked items and dessert or 12 piece nigiri with dessert. 

I'm glad I got the one with the cooked items. Those were the best dishes of the night: miso cod, chawanmushi, and mushroom soup. All very good. For the nigiri and sashami-the knife work was bad, pieces were small and the rice was barley there. Some fishes were bland, had crunchy texture, and wasn't fresh. The last piece was toro and it was sooooooooooooooooo oily that it squirted all in my mouth that I wanted to throw up. The end of the night I was not feeling good from that nasty oil. I am traumatized!

The scallops was my favorite and I did order a king crab hand roll near the end that was delicious. My friend loved her uni. 

Service is friendly, but super slow.
author: Karen H.

description: Beautifully presented and delicious dishes. Sashimi was fresh and came from various regions of the world. They have 2 types of omakase to choose from. The restaurant itself is a bit small but cozy. Service was excellent.
author: Julie L.

description:
Great new sushi spot. Four of us had the omakase menu which included appetizers, sashimi, nigiri sushi, soup and dessert. All very, very good! And very Japanese! 

Excellent traditional dishes, sashimi and nigiri. No American-style rolls (only negi-toro and kampyo at the end of dinner). Also a good sake selection and a few beers, etc.

Very friendly staff. Small place, but feels spacious. Maybe not ideal if you are in a hurry, but perfect if you want very good food, great service and a relaxing evening.
author: Adrian F.

description: Great spot in japantown.  Price for omakase is fair. Been here twice. Did not disappoint.
author: Michael T.

description:
I went to An yesterday to try their $80 omakase; it didn't disappoint. In fact, it was perfectly executed and well worth its price point. Every dish came out with stunning presentation and exceptional taste. The sushi chef was very kind, patient, and welcoming, and our hostess handled our service with eloquence, enthusiasm, and efficiency.

The best courses, no doubt, were the chawanmushi with ikura (egg custard with salmon roe) and the miso-marinated black cod. I was eavesdropping on the chef's conversation with another client: he was explaining that his original culinary experience came from his family's hot food restaurant in Japan. Don't think this doesn't speak to his sushi skills though - his preparation of the sashimi and nigiri was excellent nonetheless.

They also have $50/75 nigiri omakases and several sashimi omakase options, if you only want the fish. But I highly advise you to get the whole experience!
author: Chris W.

description: Where the Ino sushi used to be. Just reopened recently. My wife and I have been trying to dine here for two straight nights and both times were turned away because they were full. From the menu they post at the door looks like it's sushi focused. Will try again later, seems pretty good. $30 dollars per person minimum and all fishes are fresh.
author: William C.

description:
My friend and I were planning to have dinner in Japantown this evening, and he suggested trying out this restaurant which is at the location of the former Ino Restaurant. (That for a long time was my friend's favorite sushi restaurant in SF but in the end he stopped going because of bad experience with the chef's attitude and behavior.)

We went in and was greeted by a very pleasant (and cute) hostess. We found out from her after we were seated that today is the restaurant's Grand Opening. There was no banner or anything saying so. It's nice they chose to do it with little fanfare.

This restaurant is pretty much all about sushi. There are some warm appetizers but no cooked dishes.  The menu showed a large variety of nigiri choices, which price shown being per piece.  There's also omakase sashimi on the menu, which was my selection. I chose the 10 piece sashimi with five different types of fish. I liked it very much. Tonight's choice included blue fin tuna, a scallop selection. and three other kind of "specialty" fish (this is versus the ordinary, run-of-the-mill selections).  For $37 it would be something I'd definitely come back for. Also very good was the tempura shisamo appetizer both my friend and ordered. For $6 (I think it was) you get two pieces of the smelt and it comes with a bit of wasabi salt on the side.

My one disappointment (if it can be called that) was their hot sake only comes in the small 150-ml size for $8. Next time I'll likely go for the beer instead which had selections that were fairly priced on the menu.

We were not the first customer into the restaurant because there were parties already seated at the sushi bar. However, we became the first paying customers since we finished and paid our bill ahead of the others.

Will definitely return and hope the good impression I got this first time continues. Also helps if the cute and nice hostess continues to be there. :)
author: H K.

description:
Whomever rated this place 3+ hasn't had real sushi yet. This place is a joke. Here are things I didn't like.
1) Terrible low grade ingredients.(No taste except one) 
2) Texture, temperature of rice was totally off.(rough and warm. no sweetness) 
3) I constantly had to take the dish from the chef over the bar.
 I can't believe I paid to eat here. I was hoping something similar to Kinjo as they claim to do "affordable, but authentic omakase." I'd rather go to a Chinese owned sushi bar and pay 40 dollars to have omakase. Seriously I had better.

Here is a tip for everyone. Authentic/high-end sushi bars never serve ankimo(monk fish liver).
author: J S.

description:
Wagyu, Uni, Tuna Toro, Hamachi Toro, Amaebi, Ankimo, Negihama hr...2 of them, Scallop, Fried Smelt, Tamago and some other specials...

That was more order. Follow me and I will provide you with your own omakase :) Opted in to do al la carte instead of omakase. whenever I have the option to go by per piece orders, that's what I typically go for. I know what I want and it's not a big deal if I missed out on a small dish of fruits mixed in yuzu, or somethin. I always make sure the chef let's me know if there is a must have item on his menu just in case. 

Location : they took over Ino Sushi in jtown. Good bye Ino...I enjoyed you while you were around  

Dont come here because it's a small place, and you'll just make my wait time for a reservation that much longer :P
author: .I I.

description:
My boyfriend had been raving about this place for months and last week I finally went with him. We both did the Omakase (12pc Nigiri) and ended up getting an additional 3 pieces (each). 

Aside from a clam that I didn't love everything else was amazing. My favorites were definitely the halibut, sardine, barracuda (which had a smoky seared skin and then the fish itself was slightly sweet -- which was insane!), uni, bonito and wagyu. The sushi chef was also so nice and adorable and apparently is a dead head and was telling some good stories.

Only downside is probably the price but it's the perfect place for a date night or special occasion. Can't wait to go back!
author: DeAnna C.

description: The price is good, the sushi was very outstanding. Before I think sushi Yosemite was the best but not anymore, I like this one more the price with same or even better quality.   Definitely will go back.
author: Meichelle L.

description: Intimate restaurant with very fresh and very buttery sushi. We got the omakase and were blown away by everything. It was a great experience with wonderful food. I'd definitely recommend An.
author: Fulton B.

description:
Simple, classic, clean.  I felt like I was in someone's home.  Ayumi our waiter (I'm so sorry for spelling your name wrong) was lovely, professional and detailed. I would gladly bring my entire family here if they enjoyed the more delicate things in life, alas they would rather havre burgers. 
End of story, will be back and suggest everyone try's this place.
author: Captain Muffin D.

description: This is top notch sushi. What else is there to say? Don't come expecting rolls and such..it's place for people who like fish...raw. fresh fish.
author: Toni T.

description:
My better half and I stumbled on An when struck by a craving for sushi during our summer visit to San Francisco. We had a delightful dinner in this tasteful but unpretentious sushi restaurant.

Although we had the address (and reservation) in hand, we walked right by An's unprepossessing front door in a back hallway of the Japantown mall. We became unsure of our spur of the moment choice, but entering the dining room was like stepping into a warm embrace; the husband and wife owners, Kiyoshi and Ayumi, have created a spare yet cozy, thoughtfully appointed space in which to partake of an expertly prepared Japanese meal. It was pure pleasure to meet them and experience their personalities and commitment as manifested in their hospitality and the richness, quality, and presentation of their dishes.

Ayumi made us completely at home while explaining her husband's omakase offerings. We both chose the Chef's Omakase and thoroughly enjoyed the journey on which he took us through warm and cold fish and shellfish dishes, a clear fish soup, and sweet desserts. We also enjoyed a beer Kiyoshi imports from his hometown in Japan. We don't style ourselves sushi aficionados but have had it many places and found our experience at An as good as any we've had.
author: Pat B.

description: came here to celebrate a gf's girlfriend and LOVED IT. best omakase experience in the past year, i believe - everything was expertly made, and prices are so reasonable! we brought a bottle of grgich sauv blanc (corkage is only $20) and proceeded with chef's omakase which includes appetizers, hot items, 7 piece nigiri, and dessert. it is $80 - ridiculously amazing. we added some uni, unagi, and tamago at the end even.  i would come back again and again! and the chefs are really nice + funny, and drink with you!
author: Christina L.

description: Amazing food and low key feel, one of my favorites as many other good places have similarly good food and a lot more pretension
author: Jonathan P.

description:
Came here for Valentine's Day and absolutely loved the food and the ambiance. For a notoriously busy and hectic holiday, Valentine's Day at An was delicious, welcoming, and free of distractions. 

The food was delicious - the fish was fresher than any sushi I've had in the Bay. Each dish that came out was simple and amazing. Highlights of the omakase included: toro, uni, red snapper, and the zensai - which was ankimo with black truffle and ponzu jelly. The restaurant itself is small, and reservations are a tad old school (had to call a few times), but I loved the simple, no-frills feel of An.
author: Clara V.

description: I've been a fan of Koo for years and this is even better.  The omakaze is soo good with all kinds of fish and kitchen items.  They seem to always have kinmadai which is my favorite fish and the new restaurant is in JapanTown with far easier parking than their former UCSF location. Love to hit An and then off to Mari's or Festa for some drunken Karaoke!
author: Matt F.

description:
We loved Ino when it was here, so we decided to give An a chance. It's a tiny place - very like what you would find in Japan - so we made a reservation just to be on the safe and we'd recommend that you make a reservation, too. We didn't really need it as we were there when they opened at 5:30 but it was filling up when we left an hour later. 

We weren't disappointed! The chefs were very friendly and the food was impeccable. Our chef was friendly and informative and everything was prepared just right. We both had the Chef's Omakase ($80 per person) and enjoyed everything from the starter (ankimo and amaebi with a small salad on the side) to the dessert (homemade strawberry sorbet) by way of delicious nigiri, black cod in miso sauce, and soup). It hard to single out anything as being better than anything else but the file fish and Hokkaido scallop were truly outstanding!

Although we didn't have any this time, they also have an excellent choice of sake - we will definitely try that only next trip! We wants to keep our palates clear for the food but next time we will ask for their recommendation as to a good sake to complement the food. 

This will be our go-to place whenever we are in the City for a show at the Fillmore. Every serving was carefully and attractively presented on a variety of lovely Japanese pottery. Service was equally careful and our hostess was very attentive (but didn't hover).
author: David C.

description: One of the best sushi experiences of my life. Everything was out of this world delicious. Omakase is the way to go!
author: Marcela C.

description:
We thought it was better than Kusakabe and Maruya. This could, of course, be because we made reservations at 9:25, arrived at 9:30 and were the only people at the bar. So we received special attention. But the place is so small that I suspect everyone gets special attention. 

Kiyoshi San is a delight. Sit at the bar and talk to him - he's been in the restaurant business his whole life and started wielding a knife at age 5. I didn't know much about him before walking into An but from what I've gathered after a quick Google search, he was one of the first sushi chefs in America and pretty much invented (at least popularized) Americanized sushi - rolls with mayonnaise etc.  Kiyoshi San is *not* serving Americanized sushi at An. He is serving exceptional omakase.  

Standouts for us were the chawanmushi, Arctic char, Japanese grouper, Shima-Aji, the Uni...actually everything was great and unique. I'd say the toro was excellent (it was) but when is toro bad?

We rushed to make it in time for our 9:30pm reservation. My suggestion is that you rush to make a reservation here too before it gets too popular.
author: Kimberly L.

description: The quality of the omakase is okay. Not bad, but also not amazing. The chief was not engaging enough in my opinion. End up paying $120 on the meal. The highlight was the oh-toro. But other than that, everything just met expectation.
author: Han F.

description:
We eat a lot of sushi and this is the best we've had in the city! Highly recommended. 

AJR is owned by a wonderful couple and is run by 4 people total. Chef Minoru (not the owner) is so wonderful and friendly and we really enjoyed our omakase while chatting with him.  The owner is also a chef and very friendly. The welcoming environment was highly appreciated and the down to earth, genuine attitude was refreshing. 

The sushi was excellent. The fish was fresh and kept simple. The steamed soup was my favorite as it was so flavorful and unique. The amberjack and o-toro were amazing. 

Highly recommended to anyone that appreciated fresh sushi from genuine and experienced chefs.
author: Shireen J.

description:
Yet another reason I love all things culinary in Japan town. Hands down the best Japanese restaurants and markets, as one would expect!

I had the pleasure of dining at An in their infancy and you would have never known the restaurant was a newcomer. The husband / wife duo have got this restaurant down pat. Super impressive for a newer J-town spot. Under the same ownership as Koo, Chef Hayakawa, his wife, and the one other staff member delivered an amazing meal. An is a discreet, 16-seater restaurant inside the mall. An unassuming, ambitious undertaking indeed. 

We absolutely loved our omakase meal. For $80, we noshed on some incredibly unique dishes as well as some familiar favorites. My personal favorite was the chawanmashi but every dish was memorable. There are several a la carte options but the omakase is an amazing deal. 

I truly cherish culinary experiences like we had at An. A lovely, intimate ambiance that showcased wonderful cuisine and tradition.
author: Brianna M.

description:
Came here for my girlfriend's birthday dinner with a party of four and a reservation at 7:15pm. The place wasn't packed until we left but there's also ten seats at tables and around 8 seats at the bar - very small restaurant. Also, looking for the place may be hard because they don't have a logo on the front door, but it is next to the restrooms in the japantown mall where daiso and Ichiban-Kan is. We got seated once we arrived and give warm towels to clean our hands. 

We had the Spoonful of Happiness and the Chef's Omakase all around. The Spoonful of Happiness stood out to me because it was the first time I had it - you're given a sake shot with a spoon of uni and another with ankimo, amaebi, and truffle flavor! You're to drink half your shot and eat one of the spoons and another half after for the next spoon - I guess it acts as a palette cleanser in between the two spoons since each had such a rich and strong flavor. Personally liked the uni here because it didn't taste fishy and was super fresh! The ankimo was a little too thick, but the truffle flavor made me happy! 

We then got started with the Chefs Omakase:
- gomae spinach wrapped around cucumber and another ankimo spoon: spinach had a very tasty dressing that was light but delicious - the sesame on top added to the flavor perfectly.
- bluefin tuna (from Spain) & snapper (from Thailand) sashimi: the bluefin and snapper were melt-in-your-mouth fresh with then fresh wasabi they provide you.
- steamed egg with enoki, mushroom bits, shrimp & scallop: this was placed in the cutest container with a lid, once the kid was opened, the aroma of all the contents came together and smelled as yummy as it tasted! It had lots of surprise goodies inside like enoki, mushrooms, shrimp, and scallop that you don't see until you really dig in - yum! And watch out, it's super hot.
- seabass: came grilled and crispy with bamboo - yummy as well!
- vegetable dish: came with mini Brussels sprouts, tomatoes and squid pieces - this was a very sour & tart tasting dish - couldn't decide if I fully liked it but I did like the Brussels sprouts. The squid barely had flavor so it didn't bother me but the sauce or whatever they cooked these in had a different taste that stood out to me.
- 7 nigiri pieces: didn't think they were very fresh which was the disappointment. Toro is usually my favorite to save for last but it was very sour tasting, which didn't taste food :( 
- soup: surprisingly not your usual miso soup, but it wasn't bad nor was it good. 
- sorbet: this was the dessert for the evening and it was a scoop of citrus sorbet - not usually a fan of sorbet so I didn't really like it. However, my friends did.

Would rate this place as a 3.5 because it had its pros: service, tea refills were on point, aesthetics, and the first few dishes of our dinner. Cons were that the dishes went from yummy to not fresh as it progressed into the night. $158 per person between 3 people (since we treated birthday girl). Could be better for the price.
author: Amanda C.

description:
This intimate sushi spot comes from the team that formerly led Koo in the Inner Sunset.  As a huge fan of Koo, I was eager to try their new place.  The space feels like a hidden discovery (it seats only around 16 people at a time, divided equally between a narrow wall of tables and the bar).

I had the omakase, and loved most everything I tried (especially the dish topped with ponzu gelatin and sprouts).  The omakase is about eight small courses, so be prepared to settle in and enjoy delicious fish and impeccable (and unfussy) service.
author: Derek K.

description:
I had the Chef's Omakase.  The cooked dishes were better than expected: chawanmushi, miso black cod, and matsutake soup were all great.   However, the nigiri, the point of eating here, was very average and quite bland in some cases.  Three stars is me being kind.  I suspect that experience can vary whether you are seated on the left (head chef) vs the right (not head chef) of the bar.  We were seated on the right and noted a difference in nigiri preparation and complete lack of any special touches in terms of seasoning.  Rice was acceptable, which was a stark contrast to the previous occupant, Ino Sushi, who is sorely missed and might die with one of the best sushi rice recipes ever known to man.  

I recall the nigiri being much better at Koo, so perhaps this will get better, but with Kusakabe and Wako in town, I doubt I will ever be back.
author: Will H.

description:
The new An Sushi retains much of what made Ino Sushi great. Very, very, very good sushi. Great service from a now younger couple that runs the small restaurant (the wife handles the front of house and the husband is the Sushi chef). 

On the more expensive side with our meal for two with sake coming in at ~$130, but we will definitely be back. Gracious service, tiny , traditional, and lovely space, and incredibly good sushi. 

I also love that they have a no mobile phone policy and as a "bold commitment" to real sushi they don't make California rolls.
author: Trey G.

description:
I had dinner last night at An and thoroughly enjoyed the food. I trudged out of my hotel and ubered it over to Japan Town and when I exited the car, the evening greeted me with a blast of cold air. I clutched my lapel and tread onward to find the restaurant. This was no easy feat, not being from this city but also because An is tucked away in the East Plaza and even more, that the front door to the restaurant isn't that clearly marked and whose colors fade into the external wall surrounding it. 

How allegorical that was as it is said that the best things in life are hard to find!! Once found, I entered the restaurant and was warmly greeted by the hostess and immediately seated. There are a total of 16 seats in the whole place, 6 at the bar and so one is the recipient of constant attention by the chefs and the server. And not in an obtrusive way but rather that quiet and space is given you as you wish. 

I was very hungry at ordered the Omakase full dinner, knowing that I probably would want more after that. The saké recommendation from the hostess was wonderful. Junmai daigingo very dry and clear in taste with a nose of flowers. Utterly unobtrusive and harmonious with respect to the food. I am used to drinking the saké separately from the sushi, i.e. Not using the saké to wash down the food but did this time, I guess because of the quality of the saké. 

The parade of sushi was terrific, each morsel placed in front of my face was quickly downed. There was just the right amount of rice beneath the cool fish. The chef had a thick accent and I had to strain to understand him but this was just as well as it helped with the ambiance and made the experience more authentic. 

One message I caught from the chef was that one of the pieces of sushi had its own sauce and didnt need to be dipped in soy and then I realized that maybe I could better enjoy the food if I wasnt drowning each piece in soy and wasabi. And so I did that. 

Well the very next piece was Hokkaido scallops and my not using soy allowed me to taste the subtle flavors which were exceptional. 

I finished my Omakase dinner and then asked the chef to prepare whatever he wished. The best of what he then offered me was the salty Japanese eel. It was firm (not mushy as is often the case), with just the right amount of salt, and I would say very slightly crunchy but not more so that would detract from the dish. 

Tomago completed the meal. So if you want an unpretentious meal that is excellent, well presented and well thought out and is carried out in a quiet simple, authentic atmosphere, An is your place. BTW, add an extra five minutes of the trip to the restaurant in the likely case that you might miss it on first pass!!
author: david n.

description:
I was so happy to discover this place. I thought I was going to Inu. I looked around and I guess I missed the sign on the wall that said "An". 

At first I was surprised to see such a simple menu with such high prices. Especially when you consider how affordable Inu was. But hey I had ordered a beer and wasn't about to leave because I didn't want to spend thirty extra bucks per person. 

We each had 8 pieces of sushi, one beer, one small sake bottle, agedashi and the miso cod for 100 bucks. I really wanted to hate it but honestly those eight bites of sushi might be the best sushi I have ever had in my life. It was unforgettable. Now we will see if I can spend that kind of money again. Im thinking the answer is yes.
author: Joseph M.

description:
Anytime akamutsu is included in the omakase, you know the restaurant is doing something right.

If you like Kusukabe or Wako, you'll LOVE An Japanese.  Well thought out tasting menu, very fresh fish.  One of my favorites from Koo (same owner), Spoonfull of Happiness, made it's way over to An.  

I expect An to have a Michelin Star by next year!
author: Tim W.

description:
Really excellent Japanese food.  The most quality sushi and interesting dishes.  Will have to find another opportunity to come here again.  So awesome!

In addition to the regular set menu items, also recommend "spoonful of happiness".
author: Jessica L.

description:
Good omakase 
There are better, but for $70 it is great 
Great sushi chef, friendly and exploratory 
Great fish quality
author: Gal R.

description:
Before I start here I want to say that this was my first experience with omakase.  I have to say the quality and taste of the food here was great. 
It is a nice little quiet place. My daughter and I love sushi and after this, some of the other places we have eaten should be shamed.
I would have given this place another star, but my issue came with the attention. The waitress was nice and very good at explaining what the items were and how we should eat them to maximize our experience, but I was really expecting the chef to come to our table because he went to all other tables/customers to talk and ask questions expect he did not come to our table. Why? 
In any event, I felt we got slided and felt as if the others were perhaps regulars and got some kind of special treatment.
Not sure if I would really come back because aside from the food being good, there needs to be a comfort level to return.  I will however try other omakase places to compare, if they do not match up with this place then I will return to see if by chance the chef will stop by.
author: AJ R.

description: A little gem in the fabulously weird and wonderful neighborhood of Japan Town. If you can't get to Tokyo, this is a good bet to feel like you are there minus the 16 hour plane ride. Loved the restaurant and loved the chef and his wonderful wife. We didn't order the Omekase and I am a little sad about that, as I watched beautiful food being served all around me, but we ate like the Emperor. I eat a lot of Japanese food and ordering al la carte from the menu was great. Many, many options to delight and get the portions you want...in the order you want it. Everything is beautifully presented and I truly reminded me of being in Japan. My only reason for not giving it 5 stars was the Uni. I ordered Santa Barbara Uni which is unctuous and sweet, slightly salty and very creamy...when fresh. The piece I got was a day or so past it's prime and should not have been served. Other than that, I would definitely go back and try the Omekase...or the regular menu. It was a good experience...and I love family run businesses.
author: Debbie S.

description: Went here while we were on our honeymoon and absolutely loved it. We each got the omakase and sat at the sushi bar. The chefs were very talkative and helpful and explained exactly what we were eating with each bite. Absolutely the best sushi experience we have ever had and is in the top five of best meals we have ever eaten. While it is a bit hard to find, it is a stop that anyone who loves sushi should make.
author: Matt N.

description: The quality of the fish was A+. Must try the omakase nigiri. Quaint and charming. I will be back.
author: Yvonne Y.
