description: This place was so good!  We got the Omakase and every single thing i tasted was incredible.  A couple of the things came with fish liver and were super tasty.
author: vlad k.

description: Solid, authentic onigiri with tasty rice. Great for a midweek sushi fix without breaking the bank. Will definitely be back for more.
author: M M.

description:
This is the best sushi restaurant my native-born Japanese wife and I have found outside of Japan. The chef is clearly a master. While the space is small, the atmosphere is warm and inviting and the food is stunning.  

Recommendation: Omakase (Chef's special). Let him show you what he can deliver. You won't be disappointed.
author: Mission M.

description: This restaurant is run by two of the senior chef/owners of former Koo restaurant. They sold Koo and the idea with An was to focus on traditional sushi in contrast to the more varied menu at Koo. I enjoyed chatting with the chefs, both of whom are very experienced and also very warm and friendly. The fish quality was good. Some of the sushi was very traditional, but a few dishes had an extra surprise (such as a dashi gelee, for example). It was a nice mix between some innovative flavors/preparations and the more simple traditional Japanese presentation of sushi. Overall, I'd recommend An for anyone looking to have a legitimate and authentic Japanese sushi experience, along with good and attentive service.
author: Eater S.

description: Hidden in the mall at the Peace Plaza in Japantown, An is a homey, no-frills sushi spot. With competition like Kusakabe and Wako in town, An sets itself apart by feeling a little more traditional. Based on Yelp reviews, my boyfriend and I decided to skip on the small dishes and go with the nigiri omakase. The highlight of the meal was the first dish, which they call the "spoonful of happiness." Prior to this, I had never had ankimo (monkfish liver) before and was wary to try it, but the spoon of ankimo drizzled with truffle oil and a little caviar on top. It was a perfectly briny but luxurious bite, with a side of delicious baby kale gomae. Next followed 12 pieces of nigiri served one at a time, each with a description from the chef of its type and origin. The fish was extremely fresh, but the ratio of fish to rice was a little off in my opinion. The meal was finished off with an earthy matsutake miso soup, leaving me perfectly full.  Although I was extremely satisfied with the meal, there was a little something extra that was missing and I would probably prefer other omakases in the city. Regardless, it's another great addition to the Japanese food scene!
author: Ashley T.

description: INCREDIBLE SUSHI!!  This is a small, quiet sushi bar tucked away in a corner in Japantown, very quaint. The Omakase was incredible--such great flavors, so fresh. Service was excellent. A bit pricey but well worth it
author: James M.

description: It's as fresh as you can get and amazing service. I tried the Chef's Omakase and left with a very satisfied belly.
author: Hector O.

description: I was a fan of Kiyoshi-san and Minoru-san over at Koo and am thrilled that they have an opportunity to express their creativity within a more restricted set of parameters.  I went for the 12 piece omakase plus a chawan mushi (one of the only cooked things on the menu) and of course a piece of tamago to cap it off.    All the fish was fantastic, kinmedai, kanpachi, uni, kamasu, katsuo, blue fin toro, hokkaido scallop are the ones I remember I ate for sure.  Also had the fresh fried smelt, which was like a salty squishy crispy delight.  The tamago was exceptional, the extra care that Kiyoshi and Minoru can put into the preparation really shows.  The sake list is also tops, had 2 delicious glasses of different dry sakes. I left very very sated, felt like I had eaten everything.  I went to Koo 100s of times and am looking forward to racking up just as many delicious experiences at An.
author: Asher Y.

description: A five star experience!  $80 omakase was amazing.  Sashimi was amazing, nigiri was amazing, service was impeccable!  We sat at the left side of the bar, and the chef was very friendly and knowledgeable, and educated us about each cut of fush that he served.  Waitress was very attentive and extremely nice!  Excellent all the way through!
author: Peter M.

description: We had such a lovely dinner at An. We sat at the bar and our sushi chef was beyond kind. We had the 12 piece nigiri omakase, followed by uni and A5 Waygu. The meal was delicious and reasonably priced. Kusakabe is still the best sushi I've had in SF,  but with An being half as expensive I'll definitely be back here many times.
author: Cathy B.

description: Def a must try sushi place, it's new, but if you've been to Koo, you know the old owners opened this place. So this is a must try if you're a sushi lover. Will come back soon!
author: Q W.

description: It must be difficult to fill the shoes of Ino-san but I was quite relieved to find An's effort quite agreeable. In fact I'm trying to make my cash flow more robust so I could eat at An every week or so. Turns out the culprits here have actually relocated from beloved Koo sushi in the Inner Sunset. Thankfully they kept the wooden zen-like interior mostly the same, minus some golf photos. An Japanese comes through with some marvelous albeit expensive dishes. The quality is superb and the service is MUCH more friendly than the predecessor. We opted for the pure nigiri omakase, without all the side dishes and hot food and added further nigiris including blue shrimp. Everything was artfully prepared and even with my heightened attention to detail. I was quite impressed with the ankimo amaebi in the spoon, spinach and sesame with the cucumber app, the konteki Daiginjo sake as well as the oze okarakuchi junmai sake. Pair with an Asahi dry, some green tea and you are set. (Please not ice water.) I can't wait for my bonus so I can come and devour this place again.
author: Brian J.

description: One of the few authentic Japanese restaurants in the SF Bay Area.  Owner was formally with Sushi Koo.  "An" is a small operation located at one of the main buildings in Japan Town (where Daiso is located).  Much cheaper than other high-end Japanese joints in downtown SF such as the likes of Kusakabe.  Make sure you make a reservation.  I saw at least 5 groups of people getting turned away during my dinner there.
author: Raymond C.

description:
A decent sushi place in San Francisco. The dishes are good for their prices. Fish is fresh, some of them are imported from Japan. Chef is a nice guy, he is very responsive for your questions.

The sushi rice was below my expectations, maybe only for the night I visited. Sushi rice is not everything, but it's the center of a good sushi. If you happen to see this comment, please check your feeling on their rice.

Overall, it is a restful & friendly place to sit and exhale all the pressures after a long weekdays!
author: Kaiqing Y.

description: Amazing place. Some of the best sashimi I have had in SF, and I lived in Japan in high school. The chef has great attention to detail, and the omakase is wonderful. Yes, the place is small, but the fact it's not crowded and you can actually hear people is part of the appeal to me. Great best kept secret place in SF.
author: Heather M.

description: We like the sushi here. This is our first time and we ordered 12 PC nigiri. The sushi is very fresh and service is good. We will be back again and invite our friends.
author: Sam L.

description: drove 1.5 hrs to get here from Fremont, ca on Saturday night, and when we left our clothes smelled BBQ- because chef grill the fish but exhaust fan NOT working so all the smoke in the 20 seating restaurant, ONLY 1 person working at front take care 20+ customer ( average $85-110 per person meal ) on Saturday night??? and 1 of old sushi counter Japanese chef wearing the old dirty baseball cap ( that's very odds), now I have to spend another $80 to dry clean my $5000 clothes
author: Ecks E.

description:
Two great omakase meals last week while visiting from Philadelphia.  If I lived in San Francisco I likely would not post a review to help keep it a secret, but feel OK sharing since I only travel to San Francisco a few times a year.

First I had the nigiri sushi which had 12 pieces of nigiri plus an incredible zensai and soup at the end.  Everything was very tasty and I even ordered an unagi at the end.

The second night I enjoyed the traditional omakase which did not disappoint.  The cooked dishes were very good, but if I had to choose I would pick the nigiri again.

Service was excellent - sitting at the sushi bar is a major advantage to watch the chef's prepare.

Highly recommended!
author: David P.

description: This place is amazing. I'm glad these boys are doing sushi right. You feel like your stepping into Japan eating Edo style cusine. I can't say enough good things!
author: tim j.

description: I now have a new fave sushi place in the city! Had 12 piece omakase nigiri and every piece  was absolutely lovely! A true Japanese sushi experience like what I had experienced in Tokyo fish market. I sat at the sushi bar and enjoyed the art of sushi making by the chef.  A must try for sushi lovers!
author: Me M.

description: Hidden gem...and I mean literally hidden. Almost couldn't find the place. Glad we didn't give up though. Had the Chef's Omakase which wasn't cheap ($80 per person) but SOOO worth it. Every course was better than the last. Will definitely be back.
author: Jon M.

description: If you're an average sushi eater it's 4 stars but if you're sushi snob it's 3 stars. The fish was fresh but unremarkable
author: David I.

description: Authentic Japanese dining with quality ingredients. Tiny restaurant with small menu makes for intimate dining- a special experience! We ate the chef s menu which was thoughtfully prepared and served. Expensive but certainly a standout venue amongst rest on offer in Japan town.
author: Hellois S.

description: 4.5 Miss Noboru Inoue (Ino-san), the best housemade ankimo, the heavy-handed wasabi, clean counters, well maybe not his sushi nazi style.  best to call ahead when coming here.  the owners of Koo saved their famous spoonful of happiness dish and now have a focused edema sushi menu in addition to omakase with good dishes.  ordered nigiri--sushi rice is pretty good, slightly drier type.  good ratio, mostly good knife work but some flaws, like the salmon.  I would focus on the Japanese fish; they were better sourced.  had toro (spain), kanpachi (japan), hotategai (hokkaido), uni (hokkaido), unagi, tamago (nicely layered), special Akamutsu (grouper this was great), buri (wild yellowtail, should get this), also has miyazaki A5 wagyu torched, very nice.  the king crab handroll was good and the negi-toro was excellent, very fresh with lots of onion.  chawanmushi more seafood-based and saltier from roe, could use more egg custard.  place should do well.
author: Rob C.
